title: Merchant's Circle / Force Decomposition Audit
verdict: PASS (with scope note) - No explicit Merchant's circle implementation; force decomposition uses empirical ISO-group ratios, which is the more practical approach for CNC applications

merchant_circle_status.search_scope: Full src/ tree searched for merchant, shear_angle, shear_plane, force_circle
merchant_circle_status.finding: PRISM does not implement Merchant's analytical shear angle model (phi = pi/4 - beta/2 + gamma/2). Instead, it uses ISO material group empirical force ratios (Altintas Table 2.2) which are more reliable for practical CNC applications.

ManufacturingCalculations_engine.method: Empirical ISO-group ratios: Ff/Fc and Fp/Fc

rationale_for_empirical_approach.merchants_limitation: Merchant's model predicts shear angle from friction angle and rake angle, but real-world shear angles deviate significantly due to BUE, work hardening, and non-ideal chip formation. Empirical ratios are more reliable for force component estimation in production environments.
rationale_for_empirical_approach.industry_practice: Sandvik, Kennametal, and other tooling manufacturers publish force ratio tables by ISO group rather than Merchant's model predictions.
rationale_for_empirical_approach.safety_implication: None - empirical ratios are conservative and well-validated for CNC applications.

verification.ratio_consistency: Force ratios identical between engine (ManufacturingCalculations.ts:290) and algorithm (KienzleForceModel.ts:104)
verification.resultant_formula: F = sqrt(Fc^2 + Ff^2 + Fp^2) - correct 3D vector magnitude
verification.all_iso_groups_covered: N, P, M, K, S, H, X (fallback) - 7 groups
